pastRelationships.name: Ellis
pastRelationships.details: Longest relationship; left for a residency; wrote letters Darius keeps

internalLandscape.worldview: Double exposure—one image shows reality, the other imagines if power shifted
internalLandscape.ethos: Documents with purpose, not spectacle; trusts footnotes and instinct

quirks: Voice memo journal, recorded during rain or train rides
Carries old leather bag with press memories
Guilty love of bad sci-fi films
rituals: Silent Sundays at Prairie Light Café
Keeps 'maybe box' of objects tied to unfinished stories
Edits audio essays for private reflection

speechStyle.cadence: Draws from barbershop wisdom and oral tradition
habits: Pauses before names
Empathy-driven interviews
Intentional tone and quiet presence

auntLena.influence: Taught him that faces hold stories

personalGrowth.inSummit: Found voice and contradictions in proximity to power

episodeIdeas.title: This Used to Be a Laundromat
episodeIdeas.description: Bus routes through gentrified neighborhoods reveal buried histories

episodeIdeas.title: A Letter to Ellis
episodeIdeas.description: Poetic audio letter layered with archival tape and personal longing

episodeIdeas.title: Archives Don’t Cry — But I Do
episodeIdeas.description: Darius explores his 'maybe box' live on tape

identity.privacy: Guarded in public, open in presence

internalLandscape.worldview: Every platform is a window and a cage. The question is who designed the glass.
internalLandscape.ethos: Legacy over logo. Visibility isn’t voice.

quirks: Plays solo pickup games under arena lights at 2 a.m.
Writes quotes on his arm in fine-tip marker
Always tips 200% when unrecognized
rituals: Rooftop tea at dusk, hoodie up, phone down
Re-watches quiet losses more than big wins
Keeps screenshots of meaningful DMs from young fans

speechStyle.cadence: Pensive with sudden bursts—like crossover into poetry
habits: Nods before answering
Calls people by full name when it matters
Doesn’t speak unless it lands clean

grandfather.name: Deacon Hampton
grandfather.occupation: Retired postal worker and church elder
grandfather.influence: Taught Malik silence can be sacred

communityPerception.youngFans: He’s goals, but chill. Like rich but still eats corner shop chips.
communityPerception.elders: Quiet storm. Still waters and deep game.
communityPerception.media: Brand-ready—but he keeps rewriting the caption.

personalGrowth.fromSouthside: Learned resilience, responsibility, and how to move in a room where power doesn’t look like him.
personalGrowth.inSummit: Learned strategy. Learned restraint. Still deciding what to say when the mic is finally his.

episodeIdeas.title: The Rooftop Game
episodeIdeas.description: Malik reflects alone on his 20th-floor terrace after rejecting a brand shoot—ball in hand, skyline humming.

episodeIdeas.title: City Patience
episodeIdeas.description: A sound essay recorded after a visit to the Glass Cube, layering voice notes, sneaker sounds, and train brakes.

episodeIdeas.title: Platform Timeout
episodeIdeas.description: Suspended by his sponsor, Malik walks the city with no camera, no gear, just his full name and his own silence.

identity.nicknameOrigin: Given by grandmother for his calm nature and love of navy blue
identity.roots: Grew up three blocks from Chauncey Arena; attended Tubman University

internalLandscape.worldview: Home is not a launchpad—it’s legacy. You don’t have to leave to rise.
internalLandscape.ethos: Highlight reel with humility. Every pass is a form of stewardship.

quirks: Plays records at night instead of streaming
Rides transit alone weekly to reconnect with the city
Keeps a boot tray older than his fame
rituals: Sunrise journaling
Hands-on smoothie prep with no machines
Evening walks without earbuds

speechStyle.cadence: Measured and low, with warmth beneath the quiet
habits: Speaks with eye contact and economy
Quotes family often, especially his mom and grandfather
Prefers gestures over grandstanding

residence.style: Understated luxury with skyline and park views
residence.details: Wood, stone, navy accents, panoramic terrace, framed photo of his mom

mother.occupation: Former concessions worker at old arena
mother.influence: Rooted him in humility and service

publicPerception.youth: Hero who didn’t leave to become great

career.style: Visionary passer, offbeat tempo, surgical pivots
publicMoments: Game-winning shot in semifinals, followed by silent homage at Market Square mural
Live appearance at Glass Cube youth forum

offSeasonHabits.training: Morning runs in Moss Row with Malik Hampton
offSeasonHabits.mentorship: Godparent to a child in Tilson Walk
offSeasonHabits.collaborations: Sneaker design donations through GritLab for inclusive gear prototyping

style.vibe: Elevated minimalism, rich texture, no flash
style.habits: Buys sparingly but precisely—each item meaningful

hangouts: Sunset train rides just to feel the city shift

background.hometown: East Hollow, near Gold Town West Station

residence.description: Lower-wealth corridor with community resilience; lives in a modest unit above an abandoned dry cleaners

formerIncarceration.details: Recently released after serving time for a nonviolent theft charge

internalLandscape.worldview: Still unfolding—trying to build forward without forgetting the cost behind him
internalLandscape.ethos: Repair as resilience; motion as hope

quirks: Keeps detention ID photo in a plastic capsule
Listens to dubbed-over cassette tapes on an old Walkman
Designs personal websites with affirmations hidden in the code
rituals: Rooftop alone time at dusk
Invisible ink messages for family members
Cracked pencil sketches of people on the train

speechStyle.cadence: Quiet and slow, building trust before expression
habits: Flinches slightly when complimented
Smiles more when he thinks no one’s looking
Pauses often—like he’s checking if it’s safe to be honest

publicPerception.community: Still unknown by most—but those who’ve spoken with him call him ‘steady’
publicPerception.peers: Smart, surprising—‘the guy who’s always drawing or fixing something’
publicPerception.faculty: Emerging potential; someone who’ll matter if he keeps showing up

routine.morning: Up before sunrise, toast and Walkman tape listening
routine.commute: Blue Line ride from Gold Town West to Brookmere—usually early hours
routine.studies: Digital media and self-taught HTML exploration
routine.evening: Rooftop solitude or quiet sketching near the train wall

education.notes: Completed through night school while parenting

child.name: Kemi
child.personality: Imaginative, book-loving, insists her name means 'light after the storm'

family.coParenting: Solo by choice; maintains distant but open communication with Kemi’s father, who lives out of state

residence.details: Inherited from great-aunt; filled with glass teacups, heirloom quilts, and library tote bags

internalLandscape.ethos: Change the system without losing your voice or your joy
internalLandscape.reputation: The calm in the eye of civic storms

quirks: Watches Nina Simone clips with captions and jelly jar wine
Saves notes and trinkets in a tin labeled 'emergency wonders'
Writes love poems on the backs of unused policy memos
rituals: Morning mirror affirmations with daughter
Lunches at The Paper Yard café reviewing amendments
Weekly window index cards facing the Red Line with public encouragements

speechStyle.cadence: Calm, firm, and a touch maternal
habits: Never interrupts, but never repeats herself
Finishes a point with a knowing pause
Can disarm aggression with strategic warmth

routine.morning: Walks to the Red Line with tea and a civic quote mug
routine.commute: Union Hollow Station to Civic Center offices
routine.workday: Analyzes family service budgets, equity policies, and neighborhood planning proposals
routine.evening: Storytime with Kemi, then solo jazz reflection or writing

publicPerception.neighbors: The one who always has extra tote bags and thoughtful questions
publicPerception.community: Seen as a bridge between old Hollow values and new city dynamics

name: Beaumont Langford III
role: Prestigious Member of Langford Summit Club

background.lineage: Great-grandson of Archibald Langford, club co-founder and early civic financier
background.education: Alumni of Summit State University and Oxford (political philosophy)
background.occupation: Retired diplomat, current chair of Summit Preservation Trust
background.wealthOrigin: Family holdings in rail, publishing, and civic infrastructure

residence.adjacency: Overlooks the 7th hole of the Langford Summit Club course

features.conservatory: Glass solarium used for private meals and city planning discussions
features.garden: Hidden heirloom rose garden with a reflecting pool shaped like the original city rail map

quirks: Cufflinks shaped like lanterns — a nod to civic illumination
Monte Cristo lunch tradition at the Conservatory every Friday
Handwritten golf log maintained in leather-bound ledgers
rituals: Morning swim in Olympic pool (lane three only)
Annual equinox toast at the croquet lawn
Silent hour in club library prior to any gala

speechStyle.cadence: Deliberate and patrician, with rhythmic emphasis on civic legacy
habits: Leads replies with historical anecdotes
Quotes obscure philosophers and Summit bylaws
Raises brow before delivering disagreement

clubPresence.status: Legacy member, Board of Governors, steward of ceremonial traditions

relationships.staff: Known by name, tipped discreetly, respected deeply
relationships.members: Consulted during civic negotiations and land matters
relationships.groundskeepers: Trusted to preserve terrain as memory

publicReputation.press: Rarely photographed, occasionally quoted during civic summits
publicReputation.city: Viewed as guardian of tradition and subtle power broker

personalEthos.motto: Discretion is the architecture of influence

storyline.title: The Croquet Line Dilemma

conflict.summary: A proposed extension of Summit’s Green Line threatens to pass within sight of Langford House’s croquet lawn.
conflict.stakes: Club legacy vs. citywide transit equity; Beaumont’s influence is tested by younger civic voices
characters: Shalice Morgan — social policy analyst advocating for the extension
Kwame Bell — design intern assigned to visualize the neighborhood impact
Malik Hampton — invited to a closed-door council session where tradition meets tension

BeaumontResponse.initial: Seeks preservation through quiet negotiation and procedural delay
BeaumontResponse.evolution: Begins to host listening salons at Langford House, exposing rarely seen civic documents
BeaumontResponse.climax: Delivers a public address from the cigar veranda during the Legacy Gala, stating: 'If memory cannot move, it risks becoming mausoleum.'

storyline.outcome: Design compromise retains historic sightlines while creating a new transit plaza named for Langford's original rail contributions

name: Amir Ezzan
specialization: High-end residential properties across Langford Commons, Langford Summit Club grounds, and alpine zones

features: West-facing terrace with city views
Transit map wall art
Mid-century furnishings with civic flair
Vintage record player and curated bookshelf

personality.style: Sharp suits, tailored minimalism, pocket squares that match his listing folio

professionalEthos.belief: Homes aren’t just assets — they’re quiet autobiographies
professionalEthos.clientApproach: Curates listings based on emotional fit, historical texture, and long-term narrative potential
professionalEthos.reputation: Well-liked among young professionals, respected by legacy brokers, occasionally invited to civic development panels

featuredPortfolio.name: Miners Rest
features: Weathered timber siding and stone foundation
Open-concept living with exposed brick and beams
Soapstone kitchen and reclaimed potbelly stove
Loft bedroom with skylights
Detached studio with mountain views
featuredPortfolio.pitch: A story you get to live inside — every nail has a memory

featuredPortfolio.name: The Fairway Stack
features: Panoramic windows overlooking the course
Chef’s kitchen with quartz and brass fixtures
Primary suite with vaulted ceilings and spa bath
Micro-neighborhood access to Fairway Commons Park and The Ledger Café
featuredPortfolio.pitch: Vertical rhythm meets curated community — layered living with legacy in sight

featuredPortfolio.name: Skyline Timber Lodge
features: Floor-to-ceiling windows and double-height fireplace
Cosmopolitan interior with brass and velvet accents
Back deck with views of mountain and distant city skyline
Smart lighting, ambient soundscape, and future Pinnacle Line connectivity
featuredPortfolio.pitch: A threshold between mountain silence and civic memory — live with snow, wake with story

hauntedProperty.location: Estate on the 9th hole of Langford Summit Club
hauntedProperty.meaning: Represents Amir’s longing for quiet legacy and belonging deeper than trend

emotionalArc.quietRitual: Jogging past the 9th hole estate at dusk, slowing to glance without appearing to

storyline.title: The Listing That Looked Back

conflict.summary: A client declines a dream estate. Amir remains emotionally tethered to its aura.
conflict.incitingMoment: A rooftop mixer sparks connection with the estate's owner

pivot.conversation: Discussion of light and legacy opens path to mentorship
pivot.result: Private tour offered at fall’s edge

futurePotential: A quiet rise from broker to steward

name: Noah Delgado
specialization: Starter homes, multi-generational housing, and middle-income buyers across Summit City’s working-class neighborhoods

features: Breeze block front porch
Tool shed converted into weekend recording booth
Fridge covered in Polaroids from clients’ move-in days

traits: Loyal to neighborhoods overlooked by luxury developers
personality.style: Button-downs with rolled sleeves, clipboard with highlighters, always smells faintly of cafecito and sunscreen
personality.motto: A house becomes a home when the front door creaks just right

clientBase: Single parents buying their first property
Adult kids moving back near their abuelas
Longtime renters looking for a permanent front yard
workApproach.strategy: Empowers clients with transparent pricing, loan literacy, and neighborhood history. Walks the block before he shows the home.
workApproach.reputation: Known for hand-delivering paperwork, calming nerves before closings, and giving plants as housewarming gifts

featuredPortfolio.name: Pine & Orbit Duplex
featuredPortfolio.location: Between Astro Glen and Vista del Sol
features: 2BD/1BA on each side
Colorful tile trim and solar updates
Half a block from Cosmica Skate Loop
featuredPortfolio.note: Ideal for siblings buying together or a live-in/rent-out starter

featuredPortfolio.name: Jasmine Court Starter Home
features: 3BD/2BA mid-century ranch
Refinished kitchen with old-school charm
Walking distance to community garden and TTA Red Line
featuredPortfolio.note: Last appraisal came in $20K above asking

featuredPortfolio.name: Luna Vista Rowhouse
features: 2BD/1.5BA with front porch and reading alcove
Upcycled wood finishes, newer roof
Blocks from local co-op and murals
featuredPortfolio.note: Sold in 9 days to former teacher — Noah threw in a firepit

signatureMoves: Carries sidewalk chalk to help clients visualize yard layouts
Keeps a binder of family photos past clients send him post-move
Explains escrow with metaphors about cutting abuela’s birthday cake evenly

trustedNetwork: Dana at Community Credit Union – helps structure fair loans
Luis, his cousin – does affordable roof repairs
Librada – a former client who now co-hosts housing literacy workshops with him
relationships.peers: Friendly with Amir Ezzan — they once co-hosted a workshop called 'Legacy Meets Livability'

goals.shortTerm: Turn a vacant lot into a mini homebuyer education garden
goals.longTerm: Create a mentorship program for young bilingual agents with roots in working-class communities

name: Abby Monroe

profession.title: Professor of Cultural Studies
publicPrograms: Open Orbit Saturdays – Civic lecture series at Astro Glen Civic Dome
Consults with the Astro Glen Historical Society
Occasional guest speaker on Summit City radio panels about design nostalgia

features: Sunken living room with shag carpet
Picture window overlooking Bullwinkle Blvd Station
Vintage appliances (mint green)
Curated collection of vintage postcards and archival microfilm

personality.style: Retro-futurist maximalism (lavender jumpsuits, oversized sunglasses, sequined capes)
routines: Saturday Jet Roast with orange zest
Synth bossa nova DJ sets at The Hover Room
Donating ephemera to Astro Glen Historical Society

neighborhood.name: Astro Glen
features: Lunar Park with kinetic sculptures
Astro Glen Civic Dome for film & lectures
GalaxiMart and Retrograde Records
Orbit-themed apartment towers
neighborhood.culturalIdentity: Preservation of an imagined future; civic nostalgia as community glue

morning: Picks up lavender biscoff wafers and Jet Roast at GalaxiMart
Prepares for lecture at Civic Dome
afternoon: Gives a talk on domestic feminism in mid-century ephemera
Lunch at The Hover Room (tofu melt and cherry phosphate)
Preps record set for Analog Vinyl & Vermouth Night
evening: Spins vinyl at The Hover Room (bossa nova, Esquivel, space disco)
Sips chilled beet gin in silver boots
Walks home beneath Bullwinkle’s glowing halo

knownFor: Leading walking tours in silver jumpsuits
Referring to modern tech as 'post-retro abstractions'
Once appearing on a national segment about the future that never was

name: Terrance Hollowell

shelterDetails.encampmentType: Makeshift tarp shelter between freight fencing and defunct billboard
seasonalAdaptations: Uses subway insulation panels for winter cold
Solar camping lamp for evening reading
Keeps thermos and journal in a former postman's satchel
shelterDetails.safetyStrategy: Stays near vending delivery zones with lighting and semi-constant foot traffic

background.formerHousing: Evicted from subsidized housing after aging out of foster system
background.familyConnections: Estranged from older brother, no contact with biological parents

dailyRoutines: Walks laps through Eastern Flats Terminal mid-morning for warmth and motion
Volunteers three days a week sorting recycling behind Foxtrot Market
Keeps a handwritten journal of overheard conversations and urban infrastructure theories

speechStyle.cadence: Measured, with sharp pauses and long, thoughtful stares
habits: Quotes snippets of radio shows verbatim
Sometimes lapses into elevated vocabulary unexpectedly
Refers to transit routes by number and folklore (e.g., 'old 42 line, back when it ran double')

passions: Documenting changing wind patterns through the freight corridor
goals: Self-publish a pocket field guide to forgotten neighborhoods in Summit
Eventually apprentice at Summit Rail Maintenance Yard
Reconnect with his brother if the terms feel equal

trustedConnections: Emory — retired electrician who brings tools and updates on zoning proposals
Candace — barista who lets him charge devices and leave notes in the tip jar
Zeke (loosely) — student who sometimes trades sandwiches for transit stories
socialCircle.communityPerception: Known as 'The Quiet Cartographer' in Eastern Flats; respected more than pitied

narrativeHooks: Asked to consult on a community mural reflecting the 'invisible routes' of the city
Begins logging forgotten infrastructure in tandem with a Tubman U urban planning class
Discovers a sealed freight tunnel with pre-transit maps still intact

occupation.communityRole: Informal infrastructure mentor in Eastern Flats

residence.location: Edge of Glenvale, near old substation corridor
residence.homeDescription: Single-room converted utility shack with patched wiring, potted herbs, and a collection of antique multimeters

habits: Cleans wire spools while talking
Uses ‘kid’ even when speaking to middle-aged folks
Carries a small insulated coffee thermos labeled ‘Don’t Ask’

speechStyle.cadence: Measured drawl with occasional sparks of frustration
quotes: They tried to bury the grid. The grid remembers.
Rust’s just memory with better lighting.

background.family: Widowed, one daughter in the Navy (rarely writes), raised by a grandmother who wired houses by flashlight in the ’50s
careerMilestones: Helped install emergency routing along the Red Line after the ’97 blackout
Quietly rewired three shelters off-record when city funds got stuck in litigation
Trained over 40 apprentices, five of whom now work for the TTA

streetKnowledge: Knows which junction boxes whistle before failure
Maintains a mental map of tunnels nobody logged
Can identify transformers by hum pitch alone

relationships.Terrance Hollowell: Brings soldering scraps and thermos top-offs; teaching him analog continuity methods
relationships.Depot Techs: Known to walk into breaker rooms unannounced, no one minds
relationships.Local Civic Patrol: Unofficially consulted about outages and flood backups

legacyNotes.personalArchive: Old manuals, switchyard sketches, Summit utility memos from the Carter era
legacyNotes.dream: Wants to create a public ‘powerwalk’ tour of forgotten infrastructure as civic art and memory trail
legacyNotes.unfulfilledGoal: Finish a hand-drawn map of underground power across Eastern Flats — he’s gotten as far as pencil outlines and coffee rings

name: Winston Thurgood Samuels III

education: Summit City Public Academy for Leadership (valedictorian)
BA in Rhetoric, Langford State University
MPP from Columbia University, with a semester abroad in Dubai studying civic mega-projects
priorRoles: Talk show host in early 20s ('From the Steps with Winston')

traits: Publicly relatable, privately ruthless when needed
personality.publicPersona: A blend of old-school swagger and new-school savviness — often seen in three-piece suits with custom embroidery, yet insists on walking to his press conferences with a paper coffee cup
quirks: Quotes Beyoncé and Cicero in the same speech
Owns 73 cufflinks but only wears 6 of them
Keeps a framed letter from Langston Hughes above his desk — it’s actually a well-forged replica, but no one’s verified it

spouse.name: Nasir Fontaine-Samuels
spouse.publicRole: Co-chair of the Langford Preservation Society and board member of the Civic Arts Council

pets.name: Balthazar
pets.description: Wears velvet booties on cold days and responds only to classical piano

pets.name: Vera
pets.description: Usually found draped across Winston’s office couch like an ottoman sculpted from silk and power

residence.description: A restored 19th-century brick carriage house with vaulted ceilings, original ironwork, and a private rear courtyard
features: Vaulted reading loft filled with architecture monographs
Private courtyard used for poetry brunches and civic salons
Restored elevator grille repurposed as a wine rack
Hidden skylight above the central stairwell

keyPriorities: Light rail expansion (including the Pinnacle Line)
Private/public housing hybrids with cultural covenants
controversies: Alleged zoning loophole that benefited a donor’s mid-rise project near Bullwinkle Blvd Station
Delayed response to utility overcharges in Glenvale
Criticism of a photo op in Langford Commons with luxury developers during eviction hearings

publicSpeechStyle.cadence: Rising-falling with strategic pauses; breaks fourth wall when addressing public grief or civic victories
phrases: Let me tell you why this matters...
Summit City doesn’t just rise — it reflects.
We are the blueprint *and* the builders.

reputation.streetView: People take selfies with him at food trucks. City workers say he knows their names — or at least fakes it well.
reputation.insiderView: Loyal to a fault… until the tide turns. Keeps promises in public and IOUs in private.
reputation.pressView: The most telegenic mayor since we invented public Wi-Fi — scandal-resistant but not entirely squeaky clean.

narrativeHooks: Rumors swirl about a potential gubernatorial run — which he jokes about but never quite denies
Underneath the flash, he’s quietly funding a citywide oral history archive via private trusts
Has a burner phone used only for midnight chats with Terrance Hollowell about unmarked civic tunnels

name: Nasir Fontaine-Samuels

distinctions: President of the Urban Memory Collective
Documented the original Bullwinkle Blvd Station blueprints for a senior thesis project titled 'Tomorrow’s Ruins Today'

occupation.title: Preservation Architect & Civic Design Advisor
affiliations: Board Member – Summit Civic Arts Council
Consultant to the TTA on historically sensitive infrastructure upgrades
notableProjects: Restoration of Cosmica Skate Loop’s kinetic lighting system
Adaptive reuse of Union Hollow Waterworks into live/work housing for artists
Lead preservation analyst for the Pinnacle Line station integration at Skyline Timber Corridor

residence.description: A restored 19th-century brick carriage house with vaulted ceilings, original ironwork, and a private rear courtyard
features: Vaulted reading loft filled with architecture monographs
Private courtyard used for poetry brunches and civic salons
Restored elevator grille repurposed as a wine rack
Hidden skylight above the central stairwell

traits: Steadfast in public spaces, playful in private
Slow to anger but exquisitely cutting when necessary
personality.style: Soft blazers, structured neutrals, a constant scent of pine, bergamot, or bourbon

relationshipWithWinston.dynamic: Grounding force and quiet strategist behind Winston's spotlight moves
relationshipWithWinston.origin: Met at a Tubman University fundraiser — Nasir was restoring archival sketches, Winston was campaigning for city council
relationshipWithWinston.publicPerception: Summit City’s most composed power couple — equal parts spectacle and substance

rituals: Hosts quarterly dinners for Tubman U urban planning alumni, always begins with a toast to the city's ghosts
Sends annotated postcards to past preservation apprentices — never repeats a stamp
Keeps a rotating shelf of city blueprints in the foyer, often changes them based on civic mood
narrativeHooks: Secretly lobbying for the inclusion of queer historic sites in the city’s landmark registry
Receives an anonymous box of mid-century signage from a demolished warehouse — possibly connected to buried TTA lore
Balancing deep loyalty to Winston with private doubts about his next big infrastructure announcement

name: Jericho Alvarez

residence.homeType: Two-bedroom apartment above a corner bodega
household: Mother – EMT with Summit City Fire & Rescue
Older sister – Community college student studying early childhood education
Abuelo – retired machinist who watches space documentaries with Jericho every Sunday

activities: Member of the Young Engineers Coalition
Volunteer tutor for 6th grade math lab

personality.style: Wears a patched-up bomber jacket with NASA and TTA badges, carries a sketchbook full of rocket designs and annotated subway maps
routines: Takes the Yellow Line to school every morning with a thermos of café con leche
Stops by the Civic Vista Library twice a week to check out engineering books
Builds model rockets in the alley behind his building with recycled parts

goals.shortTerm: Win the citywide STEM Expo with his prototype for a reusable micro-launch vehicle
goals.longTerm: Work for the Summit Aerospace Initiative or intern at a real launch facility
goals.dream: Design the first orbital platform launched from Summit City soil

inspirations: His abuelo’s stories about working on early transit engines
A field trip to the Langford Civic Observatory in 5th grade
A YouTube channel run by a Cuban-American aerospace engineer who grew up in the Flats
narrativeHooks: Gets invited to a mentorship program run by Nasir Fontaine-Samuels and Abby Monroe
Discovers a forgotten TTA blueprint that inspires a new propulsion design
Struggles with imposter syndrome when competing against wealthier students from Langford Commons

name: Trevon “Tre” Marshall

residence.locationNotes: Planned community adjacent to the Red Line’s Far South Station terminus

building.name: Summit Ridge Apartments
building.style: Eco-modern with vertical gardens and solar glass balconies
features: Exposed concrete walls with moss panels
Convertible workspace with modular shelving
Smart lighting synced to circadian rhythm
Shared rooftop greenhouse and podcast booth

profession.title: Freelance Creative Strategist
focus: Visual identity consulting for local nonprofits
Occasional voiceover work for civic PSAs
profession.workspace: Half of his studio is dedicated to a standing desk, moodboard wall, and a vintage drafting table he found at a Glenvale salvage auction

personality.style: Earth-tone streetwear, chunky headphones, always carries a reusable water bottle with stickers from every TTA line
habits: Starts each morning with a rooftop stretch and a turmeric latte
Rides the Red Line into Union Hollow twice a week for client meetings
Hosts monthly ‘Brand & Brunch’ sessions in the building’s shared lounge

neighbors: A ceramicist named Miko who trades mugs for Tre’s branding help
A retired transit planner who critiques Tre’s logo symmetry
A couple who run a zero-waste bakery and let Tre test slogans on their pastry boxes
cityConnections: Knows Winston Samuels III from a past campaign gig — they nod in passing
Once interviewed Abby Monroe for a podcast episode on retro-futurist civic design

goals.shortTerm: Land a contract with the Summit Civic Arts Council to rebrand their youth outreach program
goals.longTerm: Open a creative incubator near the Red Line terminus for underrepresented designers
goals.dream: Design the visual identity for a new TTA line — color, logo, vibe, everything

narrativeHooks: Gets invited to a closed-door branding summit hosted by Nasir Fontaine-Samuels
Discovers an old transit mural behind a wall panel in his studio — begins documenting it
Struggles with the ethics of helping a luxury developer brand a new building near Eastern Flats
